column4: .deb are actually archives, not executables, but Ubuntu has a program associated with it
We're all learning here. :)
Can you repeat your problem? Is it driver-related or configuration-related?
So, do you have any errors popping up, or what?
Nope its simply not seeing my wireless connection for some reason
try running in terminal 'sudo iwlist eth1 scanning', substituting eth1 with your interface name.
ifconfig should give you a clue ;) Anyway, it is just a fancy way to refer to the network card nickname
Wow im lost now

Unfortunately, sometimes networking with network manager applet just doesn't work out of box, IMO. Although there are other tools, I prefer to retreat to command line, which is universal across various distributions.
So, what are you confused with? Ifconfig output?
Ok, I've found a GUI-way to do the same thing. Are you on Gnome?
Thank *insert Deity* YEs

Ok, then go to System->Administration->Network tools, and have a look on the Network devices (I'm not sure if it is called exactly like this in the English version) drop-down list: there you should see your network cards with their shorthand nicks in paranthesis.
-.- my cards not there....The Downfall of Linux, Its Driver support is worse than Vista sometimes...
Sorry, what do you mean saying "my cards are not there"? o_O There should be a loopback interface, at the very minimum.
Ok, anything else?
So, you have a wireless card, and a wired card, but only ethernet (wired) is there. Am I right?
Ok, then it is driver issue.
Is you wireless built-in, or do you use a USB, or PCMCIA device?
So, you mean it was there with a laptop, you do not attach it separately, like, you cannot take it out. Right?

*sigh* Ok, I assume that your wireless card is detachable, and that it is a PCMCIA card. Now, actually, comes a problem: I've never had any experience with a PCMCIA wireless cards, although they are supported nicely in Linux... Let me do quick googling.

Well, I actually cannot help you a lot if you have a PCMCIA card, as I have never touched one, and I have to work now, but you may find this article quite useful: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/WifiDocs/WirelessTroubleShootingGuide
